title: How to Make Rabri

steps.headline: Soak the 8-10 almonds and 8-10 pistachios in boiling-hot water for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Bring a small pot of water to a boil. Add the nuts, and take the pot off the heat. Leave them alone while they soak.

steps.headline: Peel and slice the nuts.
steps.description: Once the nuts have sat for 20 minutes, pour off the water. Use your fingers to rub the skins off the nuts, which should peel off easily after sitting in the water. Chop the nuts into slivers with a sharp knife. Each nut should make 4-6 slivers.

steps.headline: Pour the 5 cups (1.2 L) of whole milk into a thick-bottomed pan.
steps.description: A kadai pan is best, but if you don't have one, choose a wide pan that has a heavy bottom. The thickness will help keep the milk from scorching. A kadai pan is a type of Indian pan that's wide with a thick bottom. If you want to use whole cardamom, add them now. Crush 6-8 green cardamom pods, and add them while you're cooking the milk for flavoring. This flavor is strong, though, so start smaller if you're not sure you like it.

steps.headline: Heat the milk over medium heat until it comes to a boil.
steps.description: Let the milk heat until you see it start to boil on top. Don't let it boil too much, as it can scorch. Once it comes to a boil, lower the heat to medium-low.

steps.headline: Soak 6-8 strands of saffron in hot milk if you want to add saffron.
steps.description: Spoon out enough milk to fill a small condiment bowl. Drop in the saffron strands, and stir the mixture together. Let it sit until you're almost finished with the rabri.

steps.headline: Move the cream on top to the side of the pan.
steps.description: Cream will start to collect on top. When it does, gather it with a spatula. Rub the spatula against the inside of the pan to transfer the cream. Stick it to the side on the inside of the pan. Stir the bottom of the pan to keep the milk from scorching.

steps.headline: Continue to move the cream every time it forms on top.
steps.description: Watch the milk as it boils. When it forms cream again, push it over to the side of the pan with the spatula and stick it to the inside. You should check on the milk at least every 10 minutes. Each time you move the cream over, stir the bottom gently.

steps.headline: Cook the milk until it is reduced to a third of its volume.
steps.description: Keep moving the cream and stirring the milk until the milk has reduced down to at least half its original volume. You can even let it go longer, until it's reduced to a third of its original volume. This may take up to an hour or more.

steps.headline: Stir in the sugar, nuts, and collected cream.
steps.description: Scrape the cream off the sides of the pot, and stir it into the milk. Stir in the sliced nuts, along with the 2-3 tablespoons (25-37.5 grams) of sugar.

steps.headline: Add additional flavors such as rose water or cardamom.
steps.description: If you'd like to add rose water as a flavoring, include 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of rose water at the end; stir it in when you add the nuts and sugar. Alternatively or in addition to the rose water, flavor your rabri with 1/2 tsp (1 g) of green cardamom powder at the same time. Cardamom can be very strong, so you may want to start with less if you're not used to it. If you soaked saffron in hot milk, stir it in at this time.

steps.headline: Let the mixture cook another 3-4 minutes.
steps.description: This cooking time will help the sugar fully incorporate into the milk. It will also allow the nuts time to slightly flavor the cream. Serve the rabri hot or chilled in small bowls.

text: Preparing the Nuts and Milk Soak the 8-10 almonds and 8-10 pistachios in boiling-hot water for 20 minutes. Bring a small pot of water to a boil. Add the nuts, and take the pot off the heat. Leave them alone while they soak. Peel and slice the nuts. Once the nuts have sat for 20 minutes, pour off the water. Use your fingers to rub the skins off the nuts, which should peel off easily after sitting in the water. Chop the nuts into slivers with a sharp knife. Each nut should make 4-6 slivers. Pour the 5 cups (1.2 L) of whole milk into a thick-bottomed pan. A kadai pan is best, but if you don't have one, choose a wide pan that has a heavy bottom. The thickness will help keep the milk from scorching. A kadai pan is a type of Indian pan that's wide with a thick bottom. If you want to use whole cardamom, add them now. Crush 6-8 green cardamom pods, and add them while you're cooking the milk for flavoring. This flavor is strong, though, so start smaller if you're not sure you like it. Cooking the Milk Heat the milk over medium heat until it comes to a boil. Let the milk heat until you see it start to boil on top. Don't let it boil too much, as it can scorch. Once it comes to a boil, lower the heat to medium-low. Soak 6-8 strands of saffron in hot milk if you want to add saffron. Spoon out enough milk to fill a small condiment bowl. Drop in the saffron strands, and stir the mixture together. Let it sit until you're almost finished with the rabri. Move the cream on top to the side of the pan. Cream will start to collect on top. When it does, gather it with a spatula. Rub the spatula against the inside of the pan to transfer the cream. Stick it to the side on the inside of the pan. Stir the bottom of the pan to keep the milk from scorching. Continue to move the cream every time it forms on top. Watch the milk as it boils. When it forms cream again, push it over to the side of the pan with the spatula and stick it to the inside. You should check on the milk at least every 10 minutes. Each time you move the cream over, stir the bottom gently. Cook the milk until it is reduced to a third of its volume. Keep moving the cream and stirring the milk until the milk has reduced down to at least half its original volume. You can even let it go longer, until it's reduced to a third of its original volume. This may take up to an hour or more. Finishing the Rabri Stir in the sugar, nuts, and collected cream. Scrape the cream off the sides of the pot, and stir it into the milk. Stir in the sliced nuts, along with the 2-3 tablespoons (25-37.5 grams) of sugar. Add additional flavors such as rose water or cardamom. If you'd like to add rose water as a flavoring, include 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of rose water at the end; stir it in when you add the nuts and sugar. Alternatively or in addition to the rose water, flavor your rabri with 1/2 tsp (1 g) of green cardamom powder at the same time. Cardamom can be very strong, so you may want to start with less if you're not used to it. If you soaked saffron in hot milk, stir it in at this time. Let the mixture cook another 3-4 minutes. This cooking time will help the sugar fully incorporate into the milk. It will also allow the nuts time to slightly flavor the cream. Serve the rabri hot or chilled in small bowls.
